item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.description:
Hi Bill,
which version of SSIS are you using? Behavior depends a bit if you're working pre or post SQL Server 2012.
Personally, I always use DontSaveSensitive. Passwords are either kept in a config table (connection set using environment variable) when using package deployment model or using parameters in the project deployment model.

item.title: By: Bill
item.dc:creator: Bill
item.description: This is a good article but I'm left scratching my head on what would be a best practice when choosing a protection level. I want to use the DontSaveSensitive protection level on my projects/packages but it makes it impossible to run them when in development (since configs are gone and sensitive info isn't saved). So every time I deploy a project, I have to change the ProtectionLevel property of all of my project's packages to DontSaveSensitive. Then change it back to one of the other choices when I need to do more development. That seems awfully inefficient and prone to error. Am I missing something here?
